segment.source: Network security Configure encryption types allowed for Kerberos Win7 only (Windows 10)
segment.target: Network security Configure encryption types allowed for Kerberos Win7 only (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values and security considerations for the Network security Configure encryption types allowed for Kerberos Win7 only security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values and security considerations for the Network security Configure encryption types allowed for Kerberos Win7 only security policy setting.

segment.source: Network security: Configure encryption types allowed for Kerberos Win7 only
segment.target: Network security: Configure encryption types allowed for Kerberos Win7 only

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values and security considerations for the Network security: Configure encryption types allowed for Kerberos Win7 only security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values and security considerations for the Network security: Configure encryption types allowed for Kerberos Win7 only security policy setting.

segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: This policy setting allows you to set the encryption types that the Kerberos protocol is allowed to use.
segment.target: This policy setting allows you to set the encryption types that the Kerberos protocol is allowed to use.

segment.source: If it is not selected, the encryption type will not be allowed.
segment.target: If it is not selected, the encryption type will not be allowed.

segment.source: This setting might affect compatibility with client computers or services and applications.
segment.target: This setting might affect compatibility with client computers or services and applications.

segment.source: Multiple selections are permitted.
segment.target: Multiple selections are permitted.

segment.source: For more information, see article 977321 in the Microsoft Knowledge Base.
segment.target: For more information, see article 977321 in the Microsoft Knowledge Base.

segment.source: The following table lists and explains the allowed encryption types.
segment.target: The following table lists and explains the allowed encryption types.

segment.source: Encryption type
segment.target: Encryption type

segment.source: Description and version support
segment.target: Description and version support

segment.source: DES_CBC_CRC
segment.target: DES_CBC_CRC

segment.source: Data Encryption Standard with Cipher Block Chaining using the Cyclic Redundancy Check function
segment.target: Data Encryption Standard with Cipher Block Chaining using the Cyclic Redundancy Check function

segment.source: Supported in Windows 2000 Server, Windows XP, Windows Server 2003, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: Supported in Windows 2000 Server, Windows XP, Windows Server 2003, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: The Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2 operating systems do not support DES
segment.target: The Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2 operating systems do not support DES

segment.source: by default.
segment.target: by default.

segment.source: DES_CBC_MD5
segment.target: DES_CBC_MD5

segment.source: Data Encryption Standard with Cipher Block Chaining using the Message-Digest algorithm 5 checksum function
segment.target: Data Encryption Standard with Cipher Block Chaining using the Message-Digest algorithm 5 checksum function

segment.source: Supported in Windows 2000 Server, Windows XP, Windows Server 2003, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: Supported in Windows 2000 Server, Windows XP, Windows Server 2003, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: The Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2 operating systems do not support DES by default.
segment.target: The Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2 operating systems do not support DES by default.

segment.source: RC4_HMAC_MD5
segment.target: RC4_HMAC_MD5

segment.source: Rivest Cipher 4 with Hashed Message Authentication Code using the Message-Digest algorithm 5 checksum function
segment.target: Rivest Cipher 4 with Hashed Message Authentication Code using the Message-Digest algorithm 5 checksum function

segment.source: Supported in Windows 2000 Server, Windows XP, Windows Server 2003, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008, Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008 R2.
segment.target: Supported in Windows 2000 Server, Windows XP, Windows Server 2003, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008, Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008 R2.

segment.source: AES128_HMAC_SHA1
segment.target: AES128_HMAC_SHA1

segment.source: Advanced Encryption Standard in 128 bit cipher block with Hashed Message Authentication Code using the Secure Hash Algorithm (1).
segment.target: Advanced Encryption Standard in 128 bit cipher block with Hashed Message Authentication Code using the Secure Hash Algorithm (1).

segment.source: Not supported in Windows 2000 Server, Windows XP, or Windows Server 2003.
segment.target: Not supported in Windows 2000 Server, Windows XP, or Windows Server 2003.

segment.source: Supported in Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008, Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008 R2.
segment.target: Supported in Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008, Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008 R2.

segment.source: AES256_HMAC_SHA1
segment.target: AES256_HMAC_SHA1

segment.source: Advanced Encryption Standard in 256 bit cipher block with Hashed Message Authentication Code using the Secure Hash Algorithm (1).
segment.target: Advanced Encryption Standard in 256 bit cipher block with Hashed Message Authentication Code using the Secure Hash Algorithm (1).

segment.source: Not supported in Windows 2000 Server, Windows XP, or Windows Server 2003.
segment.target: Not supported in Windows 2000 Server, Windows XP, or Windows Server 2003.

segment.source: Supported in Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008, Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008 R2.
segment.target: Supported in Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008, Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008 R2.

segment.source: Future encryption types
segment.target: Future encryption types

segment.source: Reserved by Microsoft for additional encryption types that might be implemented.
segment.target: Reserved by Microsoft for additional encryption types that might be implemented.

segment.source: Possible values
segment.target: Possible values

segment.source: The encryption type options include:
segment.target: The encryption type options include:

segment.source: DESCBCCRC
segment.target: DESCBCCRC

segment.source: DESCBCMD5
segment.target: DESCBCMD5

segment.source: RC4HMACMD5
segment.target: RC4HMACMD5

segment.source: AES128HMACSHA1
segment.target: AES128HMACSHA1

segment.source: AES256HMACSHA1
segment.target: AES256HMACSHA1

segment.source: Future encryption types
segment.target: Future encryption types

segment.source: As of the release of Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2, this is reserved by Microsoft for additional encryption types that might be implemented.
segment.target: As of the release of Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2, this is reserved by Microsoft for additional encryption types that might be implemented.

segment.source: Best practices
segment.target: Best practices

segment.source: You must analyze your environment to determine which encryption types will be supported and then select those that meet that evaluation.
segment.target: You must analyze your environment to determine which encryption types will be supported and then select those that meet that evaluation.

segment.target: Location

segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.target: Default domain policy

segment.target: Domain controller effective default settings

segment.target: None of these encryption types that are available in this policy are allowed.

segment.target: Member server effective default settings

segment.target: None of these encryption types that are available in this policy are allowed.

segment.target: Effective GPO default settings on client computers

segment.target: None of these encryption types that are available in this policy are allowed.

segment.source: Security considerations
segment.target: Security considerations

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Vulnerability
segment.target: Vulnerability

segment.source: Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 do not support the DES cryptographic suites because stronger ones are available.
segment.target: Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 do not support the DES cryptographic suites because stronger ones are available.

segment.source: To enable Kerberos interoperability with non-Windows versions of the Kerberos protocol, these suites can be enabled.
segment.target: To enable Kerberos interoperability with non-Windows versions of the Kerberos protocol, these suites can be enabled.

segment.source: However, doing so might open attack vectors on computers running Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7.
segment.target: However, doing so might open attack vectors on computers running Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7.

segment.source: You can also disable DES for your computers running Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: You can also disable DES for your computers running Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: Countermeasure
segment.target: Countermeasure

segment.source: Do not configure this policy.
segment.target: Do not configure this policy.

segment.source: This will force the computers running Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 to use the AES or RC4 cryptographic suites.
segment.target: This will force the computers running Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 to use the AES or RC4 cryptographic suites.

segment.source: Potential impact
segment.target: Potential impact

segment.source: If you do not select any of the encryption types, computers running Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 might have Kerberos authentication failures when connecting with computers running non-Windows versions of the Kerberos protocol.
segment.target: If you do not select any of the encryption types, computers running Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 might have Kerberos authentication failures when connecting with computers running non-Windows versions of the Kerberos protocol.

segment.source: If you do select any encryption type, you will lower the effectiveness of encryption for Kerberos authentication but you will improve interoperability with computers running older versions of Windows.
segment.target: If you do select any encryption type, you will lower the effectiveness of encryption for Kerberos authentication but you will improve interoperability with computers running older versions of Windows.

segment.source: Contemporary non-Windows implementations of the Kerberos protocol support RC4 and AES 128-bit and AES 256-bit encryption.
segment.target: Contemporary non-Windows implementations of the Kerberos protocol support RC4 and AES 128-bit and AES 256-bit encryption.

segment.source: Most implementations, including the MIT Kerberos protocol and the Windows Kerberos protocol, are deprecating DES encryption.
segment.target: Most implementations, including the MIT Kerberos protocol and the Windows Kerberos protocol, are deprecating DES encryption.
